title.narrative: Towards a Participative Conservation of High-Andean montane forests in northwestern Ecuador

description.narrative: Project activities will reduce the advance of unsustainable agricultural activities through the implementation of sustainable and comprehensive farming activities that will optimize the use of natural resources and promote the conservation of wildlife by identifying and designating natural restoration areas through a new incentive program promoted by the Ministry of Environment that provides a stipend to landowners relative to the extent of their land when they sign a commitment to conserve forested areas for 20 years, including establishing natural and artificial fencing to avoid uncontrolled cattle grazing in forested areas. Funding will cover 1) a meeting to publicize the project activities and identify interested community members who want to participate in the organic agriculture workshop and/or form a new Local Environmental Group in Nono, 2) a 3-day workshop with approximately 40 farmers and cattle ranchers which will include: a) the social, economic, political, and environmental impacts of conventional agriculture; b) principles of organic agriculture; c) methods for recovering degraded soils; d) examples of best practices and successes of organic agriculture; and e) a field practice on making compost and other organic fertilizers, 3) the production of compost and organic fertilizers at the community center for use by any of the contributing community farmers and cattle ranchers, 4) application of organic farminig techniques on at least 5 farms, 5) a GIS analysis of the farms to determine the location of important remnants of high Andean forests and watersheds for biological corridors, and 6) participatory reforestation activities by the existing Local Environmental Group in Pichán.

description.narrative: In response to restrictions imposed by the Ecuadorian government, USAID closed its mission on September 30, 2014. Additionally, International Military Education and Training (IMET) and Foreign Military Financing (FMF) assistance halted and remaining funds were reallocated when the Ecuadorian government terminated bilateral military cooperation and asked the U.S. Embassy to end military cooperation operations by April 30, 2014. The United States will continue to promote the development of sustainable institutions and processes in Ecuador for democracy, human rights, and the rule of law. U.S. assistance will support civil society and freedom of expression in Ecuador.
